commit.message: Replace Non-Verbal Communication with Pay Attention

Scaffold a guide for GraphQL (#550)

thoughtbot seems to be doing more work with GraphQL for client projects.
We would like to be to discuss and document what we discover as best
practices, recommended solutions, and issues to avoid for the benefit of
thoughtbot as we go. This commit provides an initial scaffolding for a
guide to GraphQL. Future commits can begin to fill in details.

commit.message:
Change link to scss-lint config to styleint

We moved away from scss-lint and are using stylelint instead.

The scss-lint config this links to was removed in
https://github.com/thoughtbot/guides/commit/91ebdf6a3c96a1610a2d8f59ffd6ddd4f78cdd1f

Switch Hound to use stylelint instead of scss-lint

Based on a [successful Research experiment][research-card], this changes
the Hound configuration in this repo to use stylelint, and disables
scss-lint.

The configuration for stylelint was added in a
[previous commit][stylelint-commit] and matches the scss-lint as much as
possible, so this change should see only minor differences in what
Hound catches.

The reason that it's useful and important to change the Hound config in
this repo, is because we use an organization-wide config in our Hound
account. That means Hound looks to this repo's `.hound.yml` if a project
does not have a local `.hound.yml`. So once this is merged to `master`,
Hound will begin using stylelint in all future thoughtbot PRs, unless
a project declares otherwise.

[research-card]: https://trello.com/c/n17oCxXV/712-replace-scss-lint-with-stylelint
[stylelint-commit]: https://github.com/thoughtbot/guides/commit/ac79b2614a54bae36305a0be77a65c06a7aa910d
Change references of FactoryGirl to FactoryBot

commit.message:
Update inclusive meeting guideline "Shine Theory"

Update "Shine Theory" guideline to include instructions for applying
shine theory.

SHA-2 is NIST-approved

The page being linked to is worded in a slightly confusing way but
https://csrc.nist.gov/Projects/Hash-Functions/NIST-Policy-on-Hash-Functions
is more explicit - SHA-2 is an approved hash algorithm.

If there is something other than the linked pages about why
SHA-2 might be considered dangerous, we could link it. But SHA-3
is on the new side (which is its own security risk), so I think
the real message here is "avoid SHA-1" rather than taking a
position on SHA-2 versus SHA-3.

verification.payload:
tree a5453c36832a16714ca49e6d8dedbf74fa1d7d2b
parent 5ee3d57a6a2f6d43f1fc97cc3b4281b1a25dde6f
author Jim Kingdon <kingdon@panix.com> 1555288966 -0700
committer Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> 1555688562 -0400

The page being linked to is worded in a slightly confusing way but

is more explicit - SHA-2 is an approved hash algorithm.

If there is something other than the linked pages about why

is on the new side (which is its own security risk), so I think
the real message here is "avoid SHA-1" rather than taking a
position on SHA-2 versus SHA-3.

Help people feel included and respected

We cannot make someone feel anything -- their emotions and reactions are
on them. Additionally, following these guidelines does not guarantee
feelings of respect or inclusion.

The point is to help the situation.

commit.message: update be kind bullet

Add guideline to avoid JSONB columns

These columns are frequently abused to store has-one relationships when
somebody feels some aversion to adding several columns or a new table.

The actual use case for JSONB columns is slim and specific to storing
raw JSON efficiently. With a known schema, it's better to use separate
columns.

JSONB doesn't support the full range of Postgres types and constraints
(for example, there's no date type in JSON), it's more complicated to
index and query JSONB, it doesn't integrate as well with ORMs, and it's
harder to understand the schema when JSONB is involved.

commit.message: add language for inclusive meetings

The thoughtbot Guide to Application Security

This guide is meant to help us all share knowledge and understanding
about what it means to develop an application more securely. It ensures
that we are all on the same page about these important security topics.

The goal here is not to be complete; all of these topics are discussed
in much more depth elsewhere. Rather, the goal is to make sure we have
an overview of what to look for when making software architecture
decisions.

committer Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> 1553521158 -0400

commit.message:
Add guide about pair programming (#526)

Pairing is an essential skill for developers. This guide summarises
some of the most important things to consider before/during/after
every pairing session.

commit.message: Expand PR to pull request

Clarify meaning of approval

Based on a conversation that happened in Slack on what "approval" means
in the context of code review. This makes it explicit that the PR author
gets to make the final call on whether to merge or make changes. The
reviewer is there to give feedback, not to act as a gatekeeper.

Ideally, discussion and edits go on until both parties are satisfied. In
the event that this drags on too long or no agreement can be reached,
the author may act unilaterally to merge without making some of the
suggested changes.

Library decisions go elsewhere

Keep the guides as just that: guides. Our best practices are not the
place to keep decisions about which libraries are best at solving which
problem; that goes in templates and project generators.

Move oj into Suspenders in
https://github.com/thoughtbot/suspenders/pull/923 .

Inspired by #509.

commit.message: Add a "Reviewed by Hound" badge (#521)

Add Stylelint configuration (#522)

- The future of SCSS-Lint is unknown, their readme says "Consider other
  tools before adopting SCSS-Lint"
- Stylelint is a more powerful tool than SCSS-Lint and has broad support
  from the community
- This Stylelint config matches our existing SCSS-Lint config as much as
  possible
